![Solar%20System%20Poster%20Mk%20IV_zps42d6wrea.jpg~original](http://i1284.photobucket.com/albums/a572/rockbloodystar/Solar%20System%20Poster%20Mk%20IV_zps42d6wrea.jpg~original)

So this is to scale(ish)

The horizontal distances (SMA of objects orbiting the sun directly) are to a single log scale.

The sizes of all objects are to a single log scale.

The vertical distances (SMA of natural satellites) are to a single log scale.

It's where you've been living this whole time.

Kerbol system might follow.

Anyone know a program with sufficiently good geomtry to locate and precisely measure these things AND allow good looking design?

Cheers,

RBS.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-03-05T21:47:02Z" title="03/05/2015 09:47  PM" data-short="9 yr">March 5, 2015</time> by rockbloodystar**
  
image link corrected.

"To scale-ish" is a bit of an overstatement... What happened to the Sun and the inner (or outer) planets?! ![:confused:](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_huh.gif)

I'd suggest picking a "unit per pixel" measurement (You might need a 10,000 x 100,000 pixel image. ![:P](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_tongue.gif) Or not, if you want small representations a few pixels across) and basing both location and scale off of that.

Uuuumm... this doesn't look to scale at all! Might I recommend this beautiful website: [http://joshworth.com/dev/pixelspace/pixelspace_solarsystem.html](http://joshworth.com/dev/pixelspace/pixelspace_solarsystem.html)

which shows the entire solar system to complete, accurate scale.

> 
> Uuuumm... this doesn't look to scale at all! Might I recommend this beautiful website: [http://joshworth.com/dev/pixelspace/pixelspace_solarsystem.html](http://joshworth.com/dev/pixelspace/pixelspace_solarsystem.html)
> which shows the entire solar system to complete, accurate scale.

It looks pretty spot on to scale. Look up what a log scale is.

Log scale gets round that accurately.
